commit_message:
An initial proposal of NSX + vCenter integration

blueprint vcenter-nsx-support

Change-Id: Icfcded59c40b34e98a3021fe4ab8a1d6a2bec156
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-specs refs/changes/85/100185/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Integration of NSX with vCenter ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/fuel/+spec/vcenter-nsx-support Fuel will be able to deploy OpenStack which will use VMWare vCenter as a hypervisor and VMWare NSX as a network virtualisation backend. Problem description =================== Fuel 5.0 has a limited support of vCenter as a hypervisor and no NSX support at all, but OpenStack can be integrated with both these components. There are two other blueprints already about vCenter support improvements [0] and introducing a basic NSX support [1]. But both features cannot be used simultaneously without some additional work now. If a user has already paired vCenter Cluster and the NSX platform (or multiple pairs vCenter + NSX) he should be able to manage them by OpenStack. [0] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/fuel/+spec/vcenter-hv-full-scale-support [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/fuel/+spec/neutron-nsx-plugin-integration Proposed change =============== After the blueprints [0] and [1] mentioned above would be implemented, there will be a possibility to enable both features deployed simultaneously. It's mostly an administrative work needed because all the manifests will be ready, and we need just to allow a simultaneous use of the features somewhere in Release description. Alternatives ------------ We can do nothing, but a user will not be able to use his already paired vCenter + NSX environment as a hypervisor for OpenStack. Data model impact ----------------- No data models modifications needed. REST API impact --------------- No REST API modifications needed. Security impact --------------- No additional security modifications needed. Notifications impact -------------------- Little modifications of the Cluster Creation Wizzard needed. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- There should be no significant changes in Puppet modules. Most of the work should be done on the Nailgun/UI side. Release upgrades should be covered by blueprints [0], [1] mentioned above. Developer impact ---------------- No extra developer impact needed. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Andrey Danin (gcon-monolake) Other contributors: Igor Zinovik (izinovik) Work Items ---------- * Set up the dev enviroment with one vCenter and one NSX clusters. * Modify openstack.yaml and test it. * Create a pull request to Gerrit. * Describe a test environment and additional System tests and discuss it in ML. * Set up a test environment and provide System tests. * Set up additional Jenkins jobs for System tests. Dependencies ============ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/fuel/+spec/vcenter-hv-full-scale-support https://blueprints.launchpad.net/fuel/+spec/neutron-nsx-plugin-integration https://blueprints.launchpad.net/fuel/+spec/devops-bare-metal-driver Testing ======= * Additional integration tests for Nailgun (if needed). * Additional functional tests for UI. * Additional System tests against a stand alone test environment (vCenter + NSX) wrapped up as a separate Jenkins thread job. The baremetal driver support in DevOps framework required. Documentation Impact ==================== The documentation should describe how to set up vCenter and NSX for a simple test environment. A reference architecture of the feature should be described also. References ========== http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/config-reference/content/vmware.html https://www.edge-cloud.net/2013/12/openstack-vsphere-nsx/

commit_message:
Remove redundant topic from rpc calls

RpcProxy sets by default topic=self.topic, there's no need to specify
it explicitly in derived class, unless it is overridden

Change-Id: I19b9a67072a7f3c42e3b0e4ba412241a056a79a3
Closes-bug: 1348180

commit_message:
Exit Firewall Agent if config is invalid

When fwaas config file is not provided to the agent,
but the service is enabled in neutron.conf file the
agent should exit with an error message and should
not proceed further. This patch adds the necessary fix.

Change-Id: Iaced777e3a34e9405050252b17a203689e1c1fc0
Closes-Bug: #1310857

commit_message:
save the mysql db at the end of a run

One of the things that is particularly interesting in a node
failure based on state transitions is what's currently going on
in the database. Saving it off may be useful in these scenarios.

Change-Id: I545baf4b7eae14aa9e377bdd28aa12acfe039a07

commit_message:
Make linux.utils.execute log error on return codes

Previously, the execute method in neutron logs everything as debug which hides
a lot of extremely fatal errors like unable to apply security group rules!
This patch changes this code so that we log all non 0 returns as error.

Change-Id: I7328e62269212ccd9c7950ff064a3e337de56918
Closes-bug: 1323832
Related-bug: 1322945
(cherry picked from commit 77046d0d889a8bff095083ae80a2accd0e25406b)

deleted_lines: LOG.debug(m) if obj.returncode and check_exit_code: raise RuntimeError(m)

commit_message:
Fix Client to use admin_url when querying for tenants

Previously, the python-keystoneclient was using the management_url
when querying for tenants which would return a 403. Instead the
client should be using the admin_url.

Change-Id: I7729529e8a76c6c382aa04d066f4dbc0e59179f9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/39/93139/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: reset = 0 if self.api.management_url is None: # special casing to allow tenant lists on the auth_url # for unscoped tokens reset = 1 self.api.management_url = self.api.auth_url if reset: self.api.management_url = None

commit_message:
return child pids for compound commands

When attempting to use the pid files in screen to shut down services
we are running into an issue where the captured $! was actually
a shell that we had detached from, and no longer existed.

This should let us capture the right process id instead.

Change-Id: If3952320d3f4b9e835c1ed5f9b538557fc85e692
(cherry picked from commit de3bddc5d0679fd081d6de7a66da524137898db3)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/58/109858/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: local pid=$! sleep 0 # take a context switch to let the children spawn local child=$(pgrep -P $pid) if [[ -n "$child"]]; then echo $child else echo $pid fi

commit_message:
fix service stopping when screen is not used

In order to stop services in the non screen case we need to kill by
process group instead of parent process which is often gone by the
time we get around to trying to kill things in grenade.

Adjust unstack.sh to do this in the non screen case for testability.

Change-Id: If3952320d3f4b9e835c1ed5f9b538557fc85e692

commit_message: Add instanceset info to StartInstance response Currently startinstance response doesn't have the instanceset information with InstanceID, current state and previous state. It just returns the "True". As per the AWS API reference document, the StartInstance response elements should include the instanceset information as below: req-a7326465-5ce2-4ed6-ab89-394b38cca85f i-00000001 16 running 80 stopped Included the instanceset in to startinstance response elements and updated the test cases for startinstance response elements in nova/tests/api/ec2/test_cloud.py file. Change-Id: I08ef7ed88f983b66a30c76d6b7b754222097a03b Closes-bug: #1321220

added_lines: def _format_start_instances(self, context, instance_id, previous_states): instances_set = [] for (ec2_id, previous_state) in zip(instance_id, previous_states): i = {} i['instanceId'] = ec2_id i['previousState'] = _state_description(previous_state['vm_state'], previous_state['shutdown_terminate']) i['currentState'] = _state_description(vm_states.ACTIVE, True) instances_set.append(i) return {'instancesSet': instances_set} previous_states = self._ec2_ids_to_instances(context, instance_id, objects=True) self._remove_client_token(context, instance_id) for instance in previous_states: return self._format_start_instances(context, instance_id, previous_states)

subject: Don't override tox envdir for pep8
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-04 21:42:09.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/8e875045bd426c119d4de486194e81a7782be656', 'message': "Don't override tox envdir for pep8

infra's run-pep8 job assumes the envdir for pep8 job is not
overwritten, so it can call out to .tox/pep8/bin/pip.

This bug is causing keystone pep8 job to occasionally fail in the gate.

If the motivation behind overriding the envdir jobs to use venv, one can
use devpi and/or wheels to speed up the process of building a venv.

This isn't a backport because in stable/icehouse Keystone didn't set
the venv for the cover job.

Change-Id: I32cd46152caa73e1308fdd216ba016c80a5a9b4f
Closes-Bug: #1352134
"}]
commit_message:
Don't override tox envdir for pep8

infra's run-pep8 job assumes the envdir for pep8 job is not
overwritten, so it can call out to .tox/pep8/bin/pip.

This bug is causing keystone pep8 job to occasionally fail in the gate.

If the motivation behind overriding the envdir jobs to use venv, one can
use devpi and/or wheels to speed up the process of building a venv.

This isn't a backport because in stable/icehouse Keystone didn't set
the venv for the cover job.

Change-Id: I32cd46152caa73e1308fdd216ba016c80a5a9b4f
Closes-Bug: #1352134
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/45/111845/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Specification for adding template as an extended attribute for nuage plugin

Nuage's VSP gives nice ability to users to define subnet and router templates.
One can instantiate subnet and router than based on this template to inherit most
if not all template properties. This is a very useful feature for
all Nuage's current and future customers.
Defining template as a resource itself is out of the scope here.
This is an effort to extend current nuage plugin to accept precreated template
as a parameter while creating subnet and router.

Change-Id: I4d7e32cd09a88bbe340daf2f18ec8b3531d966b9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/78/104378/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ======================================================================= Nuage - Support template as an extended attribute for subnet and router ======================================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/nuage-extension-to-support-templates Adding template as an extended attribute while creating subnet or router Problem description =================== Nuage's VSP gives nice ability to users to define subnet and router templates. One can instantiate subnet and router based on these templates to inherit most if not all of template properties. This is a very useful feature for all Nuage's current and future customers. This is an effort to extend current nuage plugin to accept precreated template in VSP as a parameter while creating subnet and router. Proposed change =============== Adding template as an extended attribute while creating subnet or router Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Will need to add following in plugins/nuage/extensions/nuage_router.py:: EXTENDED_ATTRIBUTES_2_0 = { 'routers': { 'nuage_router_template': { 'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'is_visible': True, 'default': None, 'validate': {'type:uuid_or_none': None} }, } } Will need to add following in plugins/nuage/extensions/nuage_subnet.py:: EXTENDED_ATTRIBUTES_2_0 = { 'subnets': { 'nuage_subnet_template': { 'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'is_visible': True, 'default': None, 'validate': {'type:uuid_or_none': None} }, } } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- It is assumed that deployer has an access to create and retrive back these templates on VSP prior to using them in neutron APIs. Incorrect template reference will result in failure of creation of resource. Developer impact ---------------- NA Implementation ============== There will be code added in create_subnet and create_router method of nuage plugin to pass template-info to nuageclient library. If the passed reference does not exist on VSP, error will be generated and returned back from nuageclient which will result in failure of create operation. If the passed reference exist on VSP it will be used for the newly created resources. Same template can be used to create multiple resource of same type. Single resource can not be instantiated from multiple templates. This will be automatically provisioned based on the attribute type (uuid_or_none). When the subnet or router is deleted corresponding template will be preserved in VSP as it was precreated by user. Onus is on user to delete it from VSP directly. Assignee(s) ----------- Ronak Shah Primary assignee: ronak-malav-shah Work Items ---------- Adding template as an extended attribute to both subnet and router and read it in plugin. Add appropriate unit tests. Dependencies ============ NA Testing ======= Unit tests will be added appropriately. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Fixing display order of data processing panels

The data processing panels were being displayed in a
non-optimal order.  This patch fixes that by restoring
the same order that existed in the old repository.

Change-Id: I1cdc63dae5a37171c4a56a6b196f4d25ebfbe92c
Closes-Bug: #1350991

subject: Avoid notifying while inside transaction opened in delete_port()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-08 08:36:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/4005d82c1139f1e79a88401787a25432cf390a0b', 'message': "Avoid notifying while inside transaction opened in delete_port()

delete_port() calls to disassociate_floatingips() while in transaction.
The latter method sends RPC notification which may result in eventlet
yield. If yield switches a thread to another one that tries to access
the same floating IP object in db as disassociate_floatingips() method
does, we're locked and get db timeout.

We should avoid calling to notifier while under transaction.

To achieve this, I introduce a do_notify argument that controls whether
notification is done by disassociate_floatingips() itself or delegated
to caller. Callers that call to disassociate_floatingips() from under

commit_message:
Avoid notifying while inside transaction opened in delete_port()

delete_port() calls to disassociate_floatingips() while in transaction.
The latter method sends RPC notification which may result in eventlet
yield. If yield switches a thread to another one that tries to access
the same floating IP object in db as disassociate_floatingips() method
does, we're locked and get db timeout.

We should avoid calling to notifier while under transaction.

To achieve this, I introduce a do_notify argument that controls whether
notification is done by disassociate_floatingips() itself or delegated
to caller. Callers that call to disassociate_floatingips() from under
transactions should handle notifications on their own. For this,
disassociate_floatingips() returns a set of routers that require
notification.

Updated drivers to reflect new behaviour. Added unit test.

Conflicts:
	neutron/db/l3_db.py
	neutron/plugins/bigswitch/plugin.py
	neutron/plugins/nuage/plugin.py

Change-Id: I2411f2aa778ea088be416d062c4816c16f49d2bf
Closes-Bug: 1330955
(cherry picked from commit 876c2c25e15806529f4e197cd265bc3b2184aa14)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/92/105392/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix broken Subnet Wizard by updating to latest library

Updated jquery.bootstrap.wizard.js to the 2014/7/11 version.
Updated from https://github.com/VinceG/twitter-bootstrap-wizard. 
The bug was caused by changing bootstrap version without updating wizard.
This version "Supports Bootstrap 2.2.x, 2.3.x, 3.0".

(More specifically, the old wizard code was listening for a 'shown'
event that was never getting fired; the event is renamed 'shown.bs.tab'.)

Disconcertingly, there is no version number on the file, and the
comment at the top of the file says "1.0" - which is what it said
before. The timestamp is all we have to version it with.

Change-Id: I924df2d8ad20859688db261c2185c407450b174e
Closes-Bug: 1350733

commit_message:
Add Containers to python-barbicanclient

Change-Id: I42f13d01799623be1be59d86c4713f9ef5da72f0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/56/110056/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================= Add containers to python-barbicanclient ======================================= Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/python-barbicanclient/+spec/client-add-containers The Secret Containers resource is now available in Barbican, so it should also be added to the client. Problem Description =================== We need to be able to consume and create Container resources in the Python library using Python objects to represent the containers. Proposed Change =============== Add new Classes to the client to represent the different types of Containers available in Barbican in a new `containers` module:: barbicanclient.containers.Container barbicanclient.containers.RSAContainer The classes should be usable thusly:: from barbicanclient.containers import Container, RSAContainer # New Generic Container my_container = Container() my_container.add("Secret Name in Container", Secret(...)) my_container.save() # New RSA Container my_rsa_container = RSAContainer() my_rsa_container.public_key = Secret(...) my_rsa_container.private_key = Secret(...) my_rsa_container.private_key_passphrase = Secret(...) #optional my_rsa_container.save() # RSAContainer should be subclassed from Container my_rsa_container.add("public_key", Secret(...)) # should work my_rsa_container.add("unsupported_secret_name", Secret(...)) # should raise exception Objects should be lazy, so requests should not be sent until the `save()` method is called. The `save()` method should also recursively store secrets if they have not yet been stored to the Barbican instance. Once the `save()` method is called for the first time the Container becomes immutable, subsequent calls to `add()` or `save()` should raise exceptions. Retrieving existing containers should be done via a `ContainerManager` accesible from the client object:: from barbicanclient import client barbican = client.Client(...) my_container = barbican.containers.get('https://ref_to_container/UUID') The `get()` method should return either a `Container` or `RSAContainer` as appropriate. Listing existing methods should be done via the `ContainerManager` as well:: my_containers = barbican.containers.list(limit=10, offset=0) isinstance(my_containers, list) # should return True Container deletion should be done on the Container object:: my_container = barbican.containers.get('https://ref_to_container/UUID') my_container.delete() This means that the `get()` method should be smart and return a lazy Container object so that we don't send two requests for a single delete. Alternatives ------------ The proposed functionality above pushes most of the actions to the Container objects, while keeping the ContainerManager functionality somewhat light. As an alternative, the ContanerManager could perform some of the functionality such as Container creation and deletion, while making the Container objects simple. I think container creation in a single method could get ugly really fast, so I would prefer to avoid it. There may be a use case for providing a delete method in the ContainerManager since the deletion workflow proposed requires us to have an instance of the Container object before deleting, but I think I still prefer actions that only affect a single Container to be done in the Container object. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- Logging should be done in a manner consistent with the rest of the library. Other end user impact --------------------- None as this is new functionality. Performance Impact ------------------ As mentioned above, we'll have to make sure that the objects are lazy when retrieving information from the Barbican API so that we can avoid unnecessary calls. An example is in Deletion when we need to use the ContainerManager to retrieve the Container object, and then call .delete() on the retrieved object. Ideally this should result in only one DELETE request, not a GET and DELETE. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Blueprint Draft: dougmendizabal Implementation: TBD Work Items ---------- * Implement the new `containers` module. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Testing should be consistent with existing testing in the library. Documentation Impact ==================== All new Container functionality needs to be documented. References ========== Containers in the Client etherpad: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/python-barbicanclient-containers

commit_message:
Adds keystone scripts for training labs

Adds keystone scripts for training labs which will install and configure
keystone and also populate the keystone database.

Co-Authored-By: Roger Luethi <rl@patchworkscience.org>
Change-Id: I21bafd5d43ce58ebc22029dc4897bb19104132a1
Partial-Bug: 1312764
Implements: blueprint openstack-training-labs
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-guides refs/changes/86/109986/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env bash TOP_DIR=$(cd $(dirname "$0")/.. && pwd) source "$TOP_DIR/config/paths" source "$CONFIG_DIR/credentials" source "$LIB_DIR/functions.guest" exec_logfile indicate_current_auto #------------------------------------------------------------------------------ # Setup Keystone for Controller Node #------------------------------------------------------------------------------ # Get MGMT_NET source "$CONFIG_DIR/openstack" # Get FOURTH_OCTET for this node source "$CONFIG_DIR/config.$(hostname)" # Set Variables db_addr=$(get_ip_from_net_and_fourth "MGMT_NET" "$CONTROLLER_FOURTH_OCTET") db_url=mysql://keystoneUser:keystonePass@$db_addr/keystone echo "Install & Configure Keystone on Controller Node" echo "Install Keystone" # TODO: Verify if the option '--force-yes' is required! # The Option '--force-yes' is used to bypass interactiveness of apt-get and # install the package no matter the consequence. # WARNING: USAGE OF THIS OPTION IS NOT RECOMENDED sudo apt-get install -y --force-yes keystone echo "Configure Keystone" sudo bash -c "source $LIB_DIR/functions-common-devstack && \ iniset /etc/keystone/keystone.conf database connection $db_url" sudo service keystone restart sudo keystone-manage db_sync # vim: set ai ts=4 sw=4 et ft=sh:

subject: Do not import plugin-specific module in migration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-05 01:50:44.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/db/migration/alembic_migrations/versions/5446f2a45467_set_server_default.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/5c587d07d44ca27cff0471085176ffc43d90e0d5', 'message': "Do not import plugin-specific module in migration

Sometimes plugins are packaged separately with neutron. Importing a
plugin-specific module will cause db migrations to fail if that plugin is not

Closes-bug: #1352619

Change-Id: I7a61631810d39d45916fdb700a67d0f0bc35197c
"}]
commit_message:
Do not import plugin-specific module in migration

Sometimes plugins are packaged separately with neutron. Importing a
plugin-specific module will cause db migrations to fail if that plugin is not
included in the package, so don't do that.

Closes-bug: #1352619

Change-Id: I7a61631810d39d45916fdb700a67d0f0bc35197c

commit_message:
Updates to EC design spec from EC design meet-up

Change-Id: I92531fb11f612a29ba61eead37afd71146a78161
Implements: blueprint swift-ec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift-specs refs/changes/36/112036/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * 8/5, updated middleware section, container_sync section, removed 3.3.3.7 as dup, refactoring section, create common interface to proxy nodes, partial PUT handling, removed dependency on obj sysmet patch, sync'd with trello* Object metadata is used to store meta about both the fragments and the objects; we call an object, as stored on node, an 'EC Archive' and needs to be system metadata.patch will move quorum_size() to be a policy specific method.Middleware remains unchanged. For most middleware (e.g., SLO/DLO) the fact that the proxy is fragmenting incoming objects is transparent. For list endpoints, however, it is a bit different. A caller of list endpoints will get back the locations of all of the fragments. The caller will be unable to re-assemble the original object with this information, however the node locations may still prove to be useful information for some applications.opportunity to review what options might make sense right now. Discussions have included: Yes, it makes sense to do this. There is a Trello card tracking this work and it covered in a section later below. Opportunistic refactoring makes sense however its not felt that it makes sense to combine a full refactor of PUT as part of this EC effort. No, we don't want to do this. Proxy is broken up by type of thing that needs to be processed - object, account, controller and not by how. Its felt that this would get too messy and blur the architecture.For at least the initial version of EC, it is not recommended that an EC scheme span beyond a single region, Neither performance nor functional validation will be been done in in such a configuration.* 3.3.3.5: CLOSED 3.3.3.8: Create common interface for proxy-->nodes Creating a common module that allows for abstracted access to the a/c/s nodes would not only clean up much of the proxy IO path but would also prevent the introduction of EC from further complicating, for example, the PUT path. Think about an interface that would let proxy code perform generic actions to a back-end node regardless of protocol. The proposed API should be updated here and reviewed prior to implementation and its felt that it can be done in parallel with existing EC proxy work (no dependencies, that work i small enough it can be merged). 3.3.3.6: Object overwrite and PUT error handling What's needed here is a mechanism to assure that we can handle partial write failures, more specifically: a) less than a quorum of nodes is written b) quorum is met but not all nodes were written and in both cases there are implications to both PUT and GET at both the proxy and object servers. Additionally, the reconstructor plays a role here in cleaning up and old EC archives that result from the scheme described here (see reconstructor for details). *High Level Flow* * If storing an EC archive fragment, the object server should not delete older .data file. This may be something that can be determined at the object server already or some indication may be needed at proxy PUT. * When the object server handles a GET, it needs to send header to the proxy that include all available timestamps for the .data file * If the proxy determines is can reconstruct the object with the latest timestamp (can reach quorum) it proceeds * If quorum cant be reached, find timestamp where quorum can be reached, kill existing connections (unless the body of that request was the found timestamp), and make new connections requesting the specific timestamp * On GET, the object server needs to support requesting a specific timestamp (eg ?timestamp=XYZ) `Trello <https://trello.com/b/LlvIFIQs/swift-erasure-codes>`_ Tasks for this section:: * 3.3.3.1: CLOSED* 3.3.3.7: CLOSED * 3.3.3.8: Create common interface for proxy-->nodesThe object metadata will need to be stored as system metadata.* 5.1: Enable sysmeta on object PUT (IMPLEMENTED)EC its the number of parity fragments. For EC we'll base the number on the quorum value which is available via a policy method. So, when its time to do account/container updates, only X = (total - quorum) of the nodes participating in the EC scheme should actually perform the updates. To start with just the first X would work however there are likely some optimizations in this are to explore during implementation,* Handoff nodes only revert data to its primary node (not to any old primary)*Reconstructor Cleanup Responsibilities* For the reconstructor cleanup is a bit different than replication because, for PUT consistency reasons, the object server is going to keep the previous .data file (if it existed) just in case the PUT doesn't complete successfully on a quorum of nodes. That leaves the replicator with 3 scenarios to deal with when it comes to cleaning up old files (note that the proxy will send a special message to the object server during put so that it does not delete old files as part of that code path): a) Assuming a PUT works (all nodes), the reconstructor will need to delete the older timestamps on the local node. b) Assuming a PUT is able to get a quorum down, the reconstructor will first need to reconstruct the object and push the EC archives out such that all participating nodes have one, then it can delete the older timestamps on the local node c) In the event that a PUT was only partially complete and did not get a quorum, reconstruction is not possible. The reconstructor therefore needs to delete these files but there also must be an age factor to prevent it from deleting in flight PUTs. * 3.3.7.3: Reconstructor local data file cleanupWe also want to scrub ring tools to use the word "node" instead of "replicas" to avoid confusion with EC.* 3.3.10.1: Ring changes3.3.11.1 **Probe Tests** The `Trello <https://trello.com/b/LlvIFIQs/swift-erasure-codes>`_ card for this has a good starting list of test scenarios, more should be added as the design progresses. 3.3.11.2 **Functional Tests** To begin with at least, it believed we just need to make an EC policy the default and run existing functional tests (and make sure it does that automatically) Therefore container sync needs to be updated to use an internal client instead of the direct client that would only grab a fragment archive. For now lets start with 6 total nodes and a 2+2+2 scheme (2 data, 2 parity, 2 handoffs) * 5.1: Enable sysmeta on object PUT (IMPLEMENTED)
deleted_lines: * Object metadata is used to store meta about both the fragments and the objects; we call an object, as stored on node, an 'EC Archive' and needs to be system metadata. `This patch <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/79991/>`_ introduces system object metadatapatch will move quorum_size() to be a policy specific function.Current thinking: no middleware impact `Trello <https://trello.com/b/LlvIFIQs/swift-erasure-codes>`_ Tasks for this section:: * 3.3.2.1: Middleware Impactopportunity to review what options might make sense right now. For example:Discussion topic for how we want to support this. Yuan has suggested read/write affinity changes but there was also some talk about wanting to keep EC policies limited to single region to start with. Need to determine what makes sense here.* 3.3.3.1: Refactoring discussions* 3.3.3.7: Revive abandoned patch and propose to feature/ecThe object metadata will need to be stored as system metadata so we have a `dependency <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/799918/>`_* 5.1: Enable sysmeta on object PUT (from the dependencies section)EC its the number of parity fragments. Which N and the specific implementation is TBD.* Handoff nodes only revert data to its primary node or another handoff (not to any old primary) * Handoff nodes do not overwrite existing EC archives when reverting data(Don't let the word "replica" confuse you; that's what the builder calls it internally. We're still talking EC here.)* 3.3.10.1: Potential ring changesThe object metadata will need to be stored as system metadata so we have a dependency `here <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/76068/>`_* 5.1: Enable sysmeta on object PUT

commit_message:
Allow ceph backend for nova/cinder/glance

Add a DEVSTACK_GATE_CEPH var that allows a job to specify that it
wants ceph to be used.  When enabled, ceph is used as the backend for
nova, glance, and cinder.

Co-authored-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I27845a8e60ce1a5099152f73f46c451662a6c50b

commit_message:
Change note about the removal of variable SESSION_SERIALIZER

The comment should be changed to reflect the results of the
proposed removal of the variable during the J-cycle. More details
are in the comments of the change request I625f5f4a9f128ff31aee58f2a79ee88c91dc1f56.

Related to bug #1349463.

Change-Id: I625f5f4a9f128ff31aee58f2a79ee88c91dc1f56

commit_message:
Change 3PAR delete message when volume is busy

This patch traps for when a volume is busy at
delete time.   It then logs a more useful message
and raises a VolumeIsBusy exception.

Change-Id: I689c1a5ff5e2d4c748a98615f5610a029a027e35
Closes-Bug: 1349636
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/94/110794/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 2.0.16 - Fixed bug #1349636 VERSION = "2.0.16" elif (ex.get_code() == 151 or ex.get_code() == 32): # the volume is being operated on in a background # task on the 3PAR. # TODO(walter-boring) do a retry a few times. # for now lets log a better message msg = _("The volume is currently busy on the 3PAR" " and cannot be deleted at this time. " "Try again later.") LOG.error(msg) raise exception.VolumeIsBusy(message=msg) raise exception.VolumeIsBusy(message=ex.get_description()) raise exception.VolumeIsBusy(message=ex.get_description())

commit_message:
Refined Security Groups terminology article

Improved the description; added more xrefs to the
community docs

Change-Id: I5fb8126f5bb07da58dd82973b5f2cdb71cd3238e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/27/110527/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: A Security Group is a set of IP filter rules that is associated with an instance when it is created to define the networking access to an instance. The default OpenStack Security Group does not allow any network access to Instances (so ping and SSH do not work). Security Groups are associated with a project (tenant); most projects provide a "default" security group that is applied to instances that have no security group defined. The project administrator can either add rules to the default Security Group or define alternate Security Groups from which the user can select when creating an instance. Avoid creating a Security Group that refers to itself as a source. For more information about creating and using Security Groups, see: - `Security groups web page <http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/openstack-ops/content/security_groups.html>`_ gives an overview of Security Groups and instructions for defining them. - `Launch an Instance <http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/content/dashboard_launch_instances_from_image.html>`_ gives instructions for associating a Security Group with an Instance using the OpenStack dashboard (Horizon). - `Configure access and security for instances <http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/content/Launching_Instances_using_Dashboard.html#security_groups_add_rule>`_ gives detailed instructions for adding rules to a Security Group. -
deleted_lines: Sets of IP filter rules that are applied to an instance's networking. Most projects provide a "default" security group that is applied to instances that have no security group defined. See the `Security groups web page <http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/openstack-ops/content/security_groups.html>`_ for more information. Avoid creating a secure group that refers to itself as a source.

commit_message:
Add migration placeholders

Unfortunately we've forgotten to include migration
placeholders for backports which was discovered recently
when we wanted to backport a migration.

This patch just adds some placeholders so we don't run into
this again.

Change-Id: I5a6d5927df3433b778cf82c2705e0a1d32e0483d

commit_message:
Revert "Adding haproxy reload check"

Unfortunately haproxy reload on Fedora is broken, so this is
causing major issues in CI.  Reverting for now until we can
come up with a proper fix.

This reverts commit d9a348837693b649a212c9ac612e0f1ee3808934.

Change-Id: I951413ad04bb37297331f4a7e5485aaa771b7282
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/91/112091/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: if service haproxy status; then service haproxy reload else service haproxy restart fi

commit_message:
Scheduler: throw exception if no configured affinity filter

If the scheduler hint indicates that the scheduling should perform
either anti-affinity or affinity scheduling and the relevant filter
is not configured then a NoValidHost exception will be thrown.

This is valuable if an existing OpenStack installation is running
and these filters are not defined after an upgrade.

Change-Id: I79bb44ad7481b3ff924687a8d6afdd6c715c0b59
Closes-bug: #1302238
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/94/85594/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Support building wheels (PEP-427)

Universal is used to identify pure-Python module(by bdist_wheel). For
these, it is sufficient to build a wheel with _any_ Python ABI version
and publish that to PyPI (by whatever means).

Change-Id: I3b28ebd60ebb62fe4dcf4355b37402cfdc500838

commit_message:
Add ".copy" before extension when copying a Swift object.

When the object has no extension the string is appended to the end:
test.pdf => test.copy.pdf
test => test.copy

Change-Id: I50077f6c7a7295ebb7caf7500a5738a856e6a435
Closes-Bug: #1231544

commit_message:
Update oslo.vmware to version 0.5

The version has the following additions:
1. SPBM support
2. Support for extension - enable Nova to indicate that an instance is
   owned by OpenStack
3. Better logging
4. Translations hints

This will be used for the following:
1. Nova blueprint use-oslo-vmware
2. Nova blueprint vmware-spbm-support

Change-Id: Ia5eb341ca93bd83970fdc6c171fc92f1326e9c5a

commit_message:
Try always restarting haproxy

haproxy failures are killing the gate right now.  It looks like the
problem is reloads failing, so see if always restarting works around
the issue.

I'm aware this isn't an acceptable solution, but it should help
narrow down the problem.

Change-Id: Ide6d7de3810f15da4b23b5bdac001b8beedd67a2

commit_message:
Move Cisco VPN RESTapi URI strings to constants

Cisco VPN RESTapi URI strings are currently spread out
throughout the cisco vpn device driver code. This create
challenge towards consistently using REST resource identifiers
as this code gets enhanced in the future. This change moves
those URIs as string contents towards the top of the device
driver file.

This addresses the review comment received during the
cisco-vpnaas BP implementation.

Change-Id: I17e02cca95b1d14d9218f1a2745780bd14c9f89d
Closes-Bug: #1313801

commit_message:
TEMPLATE_DIRS must be a tuple

With Django 1.7, TEMPLATE_DIRS must be a tuple. The
definition in horizon/test/settings.py must therefore
have a leading comma. Note that other definitions of
TEMPLATE_DIRS are already like this in Horizon, so
this just fixes the one instance which is wrong.

Change-Id: I4d9aa9e716e4cf6c2b56fd25ab8fde9187fc5108
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/61/111561/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: TEMPLATE_DIRS = (os.path.join(ROOT_PATH, 'tests', 'templates'),)

commit_message:
Enable MongoDB tests on py27

This patch sets the ZAQAR_TEST_MONGODB env variable just for
the py27 test. We would enable it for all envs, but only the
py27 gate has a recent enough version of MongoDB available.

We considered automatically detecting the mongo version in
code and skipping tests if the version was incompatible, but
that proved to be problematic since stevedore masks
exceptions that get raised by a driver class' __init__
method.

Change-Id: Ib751048a9ed1d7bb33ef80a5ed9e9cf7bdf71d57
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/47/112047/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:py27] setenv = ZAQAR_TEST_MONGODB=1

commit_message:
Adding haproxy reload check

When an initializing controller node restarts haproxy as part of the
initialization sequence, and that node happens to be in control of
the VIP address but is not the bootstrap node, then the initial
cluster initialization sequence can fail.

This commit changes the haproxy script such that if haproxy is
running, then it is reloaded instead of restarted.

Change-Id: I1b35d3ebdb08e175fb0fd58c0c395b7b30103b4b
Closes-bug: #1348931
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/63/109963/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if service haproxy status; then service haproxy reload else service haproxy restart fi

commit_message:
Convert network/api.py fixedip calls to use FixedIP object

This makes the network/api.py module use the FixedIP object for
fetching fixedip information instead of direct database access.
There was not complete test coverage for these calls, so it is added
here.

Note that this includes a change to the FixedIP object, which allows
for the case that fixed_ip_get_by_floating_address() can return
None. This is technically an RPC-visible change that would normally
require a version bump. However, I don't think it's worth bumping
the version here since this bug would cause calls to explode in a
non-useful way, thus preventing callers from being able to tolerate
the case where the DB call returns None.

Change-Id: Id8a9c8d2d10ddfaf0990258ac496da7c48a9b28c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/14/109114/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if db_fixedip is not None: return cls._from_db_object(context, cls(context), db_fixedip)

commit_message:
Make flake8 ignore list more fine granular

Instead of ignoring all flake8 specific errors ("F"), list those
codes that currently fail so that they can be addressed one by one
and the currently passing ones will not get added by accident.

Change-Id: Ia40f0d832b70eeb788ae14a84dc0c40cc2e4724f

commit_message:
Adding new global requirement for pyasn1_modules

This new package is needed for TLS common utilities
module in Newtron project for the new TLS offloading capability
in Neutron LBaaS service.

Change-Id: I78b825740823414cc324df6b74945fb7f6b97932
Implements: blueprint lbaas-ssl-termination

'properties' to store root bdm metadata to avoid overwrite the
extra metadata.

Change-Id: I2224905f596690e22aa71dc6541284f005ebba9d
Closes-Bug: #1347355

commit_message:
Fix extra metadata didn't assign into snapshot image

create_image action API accept metadata parameter to add extra
metadata into snapshot image. But the current code doesn't work
for snapshot of volume based instance. This error is because the
code use var 'props' to store extra metadatas, and the code use
same var to store root bdm metadata later, then the extra metadata
is overwritten by root bdm metadata. This patch use another var
'properties' to store root bdm metadata to avoid overwrite the
extra metadata.

Change-Id: I2224905f596690e22aa71dc6541284f005ebba9d
Closes-Bug: #1347355
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/88/108888/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: properties = bdms.root_metadata( image_meta = {'properties': properties}

commit_message:
Improve block-storage.yaml to support BLOCKSTORAGESCALE

This change aims at improving block-storage.yaml to support the
usage of a non-zero BLOCKSTORAGE value.

Summary of changes:
  - fixes a problem in Makefile where BLOCKSTORAGE was always 0
  - remove from template unneeded parts related to neutron
  - uses ControlVirtualIP for keystone auth and mysql
  - removes duplicated config section from BlockStorageConfig
  - add support for Passtrough and allNodesConfig
  - updates list of hosts in allNodesConfig to include BS nodes

NOTE: block-storage-nfs.yaml is not modified by this patch, it will
hopefully not be needed in the future as we move forward to configure
the additional Cinder drivers via Params/ExtraConfig or something.

Change-Id: I8c418aa596def482e7e33540ae335aac84c808b1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/28/111128/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Register all backend classes as entry points

Create entry point namespaces and plugin names for
all of the existing backend types and instances.

Update the database utilities in the tests to use
the entry points to load the modules, instead of
searching for the modules on the filesystem, avoiding
errors building import names from paths that may
not be valid python package names.

In anticipation of using stevedore for loading backends,
move it from test-requirements.txt to requirements.txt.
It is being installed when oslo.messaging is installed
anyway.

Fixes bug: #1310768

Change-Id: I2832cf3b53ed0e331f5322e671e45581c53e7bc9

commit_message:
create pools in Ceph before enabling RBD backends

If RBD backend for Cinder is enabled and cinder-volume service is
started before the configured pool is created in Ceph and a keyring with
permissions to access that pool is placed on the node, cinder-volume
will fail to connect to Ceph and will refuse to create volumes until
restarted.

Change-Id: Ia7f0c937da896da734b7882534b126e4169ae4ed
Closes-Bug: #1352335

commit_message:
Debug env for tox

Running a test with pdb was difficult because tox captures
output and causes pdb prompt to quit.

Tips for how to run with debug are provided here:
 https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Testr#Debugging_.28pdb.29_Tests

This change puts these commands into a debug env in tox.ini so
you can do a command like:

tox -e debug pycadf.tests.test_cadf_spec

and when it hits your breakpoint you'll get the debug prompt.

Change-Id: Ic53a888e4e305d51159d1d6a2f962786a532e089
Co-Authored-By: Brant Knudson <bknudson@us.ibm.com>
Closes-Bug: #1350424
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/07/110707/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:debug] commands = {toxinidir}/tools/debug_helper.sh {posargs}

commit_message:
Group tests by class

It guarantees that all tests inside the test class will be executed in
sigle thread. It makes us able to group some tests that uses same
external resource into one tests execution thread to avoid races.
Example: tests that are use external MySQL/PostgreSQL.

Change-Id: I67f10d20ea84caa9335f909fb5f30da4b4e7f1ca

added_lines: if self.imgfile.startswith('rbd:'): rbd_data = self.imgfile.split(':') drive_opts = { 'protocol': rbd_data[0], 'filename': rbd_data[1], 'format': 'raw', } for opt in rbd_data: if opt.startswith('id='): drive_opts['username'] = opt.partition('id=')[0] else: drive_opts = { 'filename': self.imgfile, 'format': self.imgfmt, } self.handle.add_drive_opts(**drive_opts) _("Error mounting %(drive_opts)s with libguestfs (%(e)s)") % {'drive_opts': drive_opts, 'e': e})

commit_message:
Disable cinder with ironic

Cinder doesn't currently work with ironic as volumes cannot yet
be attached to baremetal nodes. This is something that may be
available in the K series. For now, though, so that we can work
on enabling the tempest API and scenario tests with ironic, we
need to disable cinder.

Change-Id: I4e2afc232986f70263425deec4b335a1a5b8110f

commit_message:
Hosts element: Use 'markers' for updating hosts

This should prevent writing duplicates to /etc/hosts and also
preserve the entries when cloudinit runs on reboot since they are
present in /etc/cloud/templates/hosts.tmpl.

Closes-Bug: #1333649

Change-Id: Icabdb423b16eb143a5ab6f62084d01e8fd4ac384
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/98/102198/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: set -euxwrite_entries() { local file=$1 local entries="$2" # Don't do anything if the file isn't there if [ ! -f "$file" ]; then return fi if grep -q "HEAT_HOSTS_START" "$file"; then awk -v v="$entries" '/HEAT_HOSTS_START/ { print $0 print v f=1 }f &&!/HEAT_HOSTS_END/{next}/HEAT_HOSTS_END/{f=0}!f' "$file" >$file.temp && mv $file.temp "$file" else echo "# HEAT_HOSTS_START - Do not edit manually within this section!" >> "$file" echo "$entries" >> "$file" echo "# HEAT_HOSTS_END" >> "$file" fi } ENTRIES=$(os-apply-config --key hosts --type raw --key-default '') if [ ! -z "$ENTRIES" ]; then # cloud-init files are /etc/cloud/templates/hosts.OSNAME.tmpl DIST=$(lsb_release -is | tr -s [A-Z] [a-z]) case $DIST in fedora) name="redhat" ;; *) name=$DIST ;; esac write_entries /etc/cloud/templates/hosts.${name}.tmpl "$ENTRIES" write_entries /etc/hosts "$ENTRIES"
deleted_lines: set -eu# 51 - right after oac as hosts is needed for $justabouteverything. if [ ! -e /etc/hosts -o ! -e /var/run/hosts.d/tail ]; then exit 0 fi if fgrep -f /var/run/hosts.d/tail /etc/hosts; then exit 0cp /etc/hosts /var/run/hosts.d/new-hosts echo >> /var/run/hosts.d/new-hosts cat /var/run/hosts.d/tail >> /var/run/hosts.d/new-hosts echo >> /var/run/hosts.d/new-hosts mv /var/run/hosts.d/new-hosts /etc/hosts

subject: Health Maintenance for Scaling Group Members
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-29 16:03:57.000000000', 'files': ['specs/scaling-group-health.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs/commit/7beeaead8d4f74ccf8dfd2210df6e682d3181e32', 'message': 'Health Maintenance for Scaling Group Members

This spec fills a major gap compared to AWS autoscaling groups:
automatic maintenance of member health. This spec follows the leanness
of the AWS interface design as closely as possible, diverging as
required by the ways that OpenStack differs from AWS. The
implementation is direct (rather than indirect through another
project).

Change-Id: Icc9df8176a0ea7ddca6a7fec4add02a7df0b06c1
'}]
commit_message:
Health Maintenance for Scaling Group Members

This spec fills a major gap compared to AWS autoscaling groups:
automatic maintenance of member health. This spec follows the leanness
of the AWS interface design as closely as possible, diverging as
required by the ways that OpenStack differs from AWS. The
implementation is direct (rather than indirect through another
project).

Change-Id: Icc9df8176a0ea7ddca6a7fec4add02a7df0b06c1

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================= Scaling Group Health ============================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/scaling-group-health Scaling groups in OpenStack lack a major feature found in the auto-scaling groups (ASGs) of AWS: automatic health maintenance for members. AWS users find this to be the most valuable feature of ASGs in AWS. This functionality is currently not available from anything in OpenStack. Problem description =================== In AWS, health maintenance for scaling group members works as follows. If the user does nothing about it, member health is monitored by polling the member's status in EC2. Alternatively, the scaling group can be told to use the health status detected by a particular ELB. Additionally, the user can monitor member health by his own means and make an API call to tell the group that a certain member is unhealthy. Once the scaling group has seen that a member is unhealthy, the group will react. As a special exception to cover the startup transient, the scaling group will not react to health problems detected during a configured startup period (called the health check grace period) of each member. Heat offers four kinds of scaling groups: OS::Heat::InstanceGroup, AWS::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup, OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup, and OS::Heat::ResourceGroup. None of them has any automatic health maintenance for members. Only one of the four has a health check grace period property, and it is ignored. Additionally there is a technical internal fragility. Heat has a DB table named Resources, which contains a record for every resource in every stack. Each such record includes a reference to the underlying (e.g., in Nova, Cinder, Neutron, ...) thing. If the underlying thing is deleted by something other than Heat, the corresponding Resource record remains untouched --- creating a problematic inconsistency in the database. In OpenStack there is an additional confounding degree of generality: the members of a scaling group might be things other than Compute instances. For OS::Heat::InstanceGroup and AWS::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup each member is of type OS::Heat::ScaledResource --- which does not correspond to any real resource type but rather must be mapped in the environment; the default provider environment maps this to AWS::EC2::Instance, but the user-provided environment can supply a different mapping. For the other two types of scaling group, the member type is given by a property of the group. Thus, in all four kinds of scaling group, the member type can be any type. This spec focuses on the cases where the members are stacks or Compute instances, and establishing a framework that can also support additional member types. In OpenStack the way to connect an OS::Neutron::LoadBalancer to the members of a scaling group is to make the group's members be stacks that include an OS::Neutron::PoolMember connected to the OS::Neutron::Pool of the OS::Neutron::LoadBalancer. The content and meaning of a member stack is application-specific, so we should not ask Heat to automatically find a connection between a scaling group member stack and an OS::Neutron::Pool. Rather, there has to be a way for the template author to indicate these connections. We should not ask the cloud user to write, in templates and/or client code, more complicated stuff than necessary. The AWS design puts minimal requirements on the cloud user, at least for the cases of health detection by polling status or application URLs, and so should our design. This problem is related to the Convergence work, and the implementation should leverage Convergence when it becomes available. There may be some stop-gap part of the implementation in the interim. Proposed change =============== There are two parts to the change: (1) what the cloud user writes, and (2) the corresponding support in Heat. The health check grace period property shall be added to the scaling group resource types that lack it. All resource types that accept this property shall respect it. Health detection by monitoring member status in the member's native service shall happen implicitly unless the group's properties explicitly indicate to use OS::Neutron::PoolMember status instead. Each scaling group type gains two optional properties that can be used together to direct the group to get member health information from PoolMember status. A PoolMember's status is normally ACTIVE, and is INACTIVE while the pool's health monitoring subsystem considers the member to be unhealthy. One of the new scaling group properties is named "pool" and takes a string value that is the UUID of the relevant OS::Neutron::Pool. The other property is named "pool_member_output" and takes a string value that is the name of the member stack output that carries the UUID of the PoolMember to consult to get the member's health status. That is, this functionality is available only when the group's members are nested stacks. In this case each member stack must have an output whose value is the UUID of a PoolMember in the stack, and the status of that PoolMember is taken to indicate the health of the scaling group member. To support the third source of health information --- explicit declarations from the cloud user --- we add an operation to the API. That is, for now, the Heat API. There have been discussions of giving scaling groups their own API in the future, but for now we have only the Heat API to work with. The cloud user that realizes that an autoscaling group is a nested stack already has all the needed inspection operations in the existing APIs; all that is missing is an operation that declares the health of a scaling group member. That operation will be:: PUT /v1/​{tenant_id}​/stacks/​{stack_name}​/​{stack_id}​/resources/​{resource_name}​/scaling_group_members/{member_name}/health with a body containing JSON like .. code-block:: json { "health": "unhealthy" } and optionally including an HTTP header like:: X-Respect-Health-Check-Grace-Period: False The stack_name and stack_id identify the stack in which the scaling group is a resource, and resource_name distinguishes the scaling group in question from the other resources in its parent stack. The member_name is the resource name of the scaling group member whose health is being declared. The only supported value for "health" is "unhealthy". The``X-Respect-Health-Check-Grace-Period`` header is optional and takes a boolean value, which defaults to True. If the health check grace period is respected and has not yet expired then the response code will be 409. The implementation will be based on periodic polling, since there are no relevant notifications available. When PoolMember status is to be polled, the member is considered healthy if the PoolMember exists and its status is ACTIVE, otherwise the member is considered unhealthy. When the member's native status is used, a new method on the corresponding Resource subclass will be called to test the member's native status --- if that Resource subclass has that method; otherwise it is a validation error. In the case of Compute instance resources, this test will check that the instance exists and is in a normal running state. In the case of a stack, this test will test that the stack exists. No other resource types will implement this new method. When Convergence becomes available, the case of monitoring the member's native status will leverage the monitoring done by the Convergence observers. Once a member's health check grace period has expired, any subsequent detection of unhealth will trigger replacement of the member. This will be done by generating a new template for the group (remember that a scaling group is a nested stack) that excludes the old version of the member being replaced and includes a new resource (different name from the old) for the member being replaced, and then the group qua stack will be updated with the revised template. Three of the four existing scaling group types are implemented in ``heat/engine/resources/autoscaling.py`` and use code in ``heat/scaling/template.py`` to generate their templates; OS::Heat::ResourceGroup is implemented in ``heat/engine/resources/resource_group.py``. The Compute instance resource types are implemented in ``heat/engine/resources/server.py`` and ``heat/engine/resources/instance.py``. Stack-based resources are rooted at the ``StackResource`` class in ``heat/engine/stack_resource.py``. The Heat API starts in ``heat/api/openstack/v1/__init__.py``, where URI patterns are mapped to operations on controllers. The controller for Heat resources is in ``heat/api/openstack/v1/resources.py`` and this change will introduce ``heat/api/openstack/v1/scaling_group_members.py`` to hold a controller for scaling group members. The controller methods do little more than RPC to the Heat engine, using the client code in ``heat/rpc/client.py``. The RPC calls are implemented in ``heat/engine/service.py``. There is a facility in Heat already for doing periodic background work for stacks that need it. This starts with the ``StackWatch`` class in ``heat/engine/service.py``. Adding stack-oriented monitoring will involve adding a monitoring method to the ``Stack`` class in ``heat/engine/stack.py``. Alternatives ------------ Alternatives involving the cloud user configuring Ceilometer alarms were considered, and rejected because they are unnecessarily burdensome for the user. Alternatives involving Ceilometer under the covers were considered, and rejected because they involve more mechanism than the chosen design. For the problem of how a nested stack that is a scaling group member indicates its corresponding PoolMember, several alternatives were considered. It would be possible to automatically scour the member's template looking for PoolMembers; that was rejected because that would break the abstraction created by the template author. For the problem of identifying the member stack output that carries the PoolMember ID, a simple reserved name was considered, and rejected due to general dislike of giving special meaning according to name only. The possibility of expanding the schema language with some way to tag the relevant output was considered, and rejected because it looks like a fairly big change for a fairly small payoff. Several alternatives were considered for the API to declare scaling group member health. One was:: POST /v1/​{tenant_id}​/stacks/​{stack_name}​/​{stack_id}​/resources/​{resource_name}​/signal with a body like .. code-block:: json { "health": "unhealthy", "respect_health_check_grace_period": "true" } and where stack_name and stack_id are those of the scaling group and resource_name names the scaling group member whose health is being declared. This was rejected because resource signals are passed to the resource for handling, the containing stack does not interpret them. For example, in the case of a scaling group of OS::Nova::Server, it would be an OS::Nova::Server resource that is asked to handle the signal. We want this call to be handled by the scaling group code, not the member type's code. Another alternative considered was:: POST /v1/​{tenant_id}​/stacks/​{stack_name}​/​{stack_id}​/resources/​{resource_name}​/signal with a body like .. code-block:: json { "member_name": "junkygeneratedname", "health": "unhealthy", "respect_health_check_grace_period": "true" } and where stack_name and stack_id are those of the parent stack in which the scaling group is a resource, resource_name names the scaling group, and member_name is the resource name of the scaling group member whose health is being declared. This was rejected because of the hackiness of the authorization technique involved --- it involves those "signed URLs". Also, there is a technical problem with producing the signed URLs in this case. The current code base produces signed URLs only for resource types that inherit from ``signal_responder.SignalResponder`` but the scaling group types do not inherit from that. The preceding alternative is similarly afflicted. One solution considered for that subproblem is to introduce new resource types to produce the signed URLs; this was rejected because it is burdensome on the user. A possible approach is to use Python's multiple inheritance to add the needed superclass to the scaling group classes. Another alternative considered was:: POST /v1/​{tenant_id}​/stacks/​{stack_name}​/​{stack_id}​/resources/​{resource_name}​/actions with a body like .. code-block:: json { "health": "unhealthy", "respect_health_check_grace_period": "true" } and where stack_name and stack_id are those of the scaling group and resource_name names the scaling group member whose health is being declared. This was rejected because the scaling group nature of the stack in question is not accessible to the code that would handle that call. Note that in the DB model of a stack there is no clue that it is a scaling group, not even a clue that it is a nested stack. Another alternative considered was:: POST /v1/​{tenant_id}​/stacks/​{stack_name}​/​{stack_id}​/resources/​{resource_name}​/actions with a body like .. code-block:: json { "member_name": "junkygeneratedname", "health": "unhealthy", "respect_health_check_grace_period": "true" } where stack_name and stack_id are those of the parent stack that contains the scaling group, resource_name is the name of the scaling group in its parent stack, and member_name is the resource name of the scaling group member whose health is being declared. Because the URI addresses the scaling group as a resource in its parent stack, the code handling such a call would have access to the scaling group nature of the scaling group. This was rejected only because a more RESTful alternative was conceived; the other alternatives above are also inferior in their RESTfulness. Implementation ============== See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/109917 for an initial draft. If your member type is a stack containing a Cinder volume & attachment then you will not be able to successfully test until you have applied a fix for bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/heat/+bug/1332991. If you are using nova networking you will need the fix for bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1327406 Assignee(s) ----------- Mike Spreitzer Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Juno-3 Work Items ---------- Work item 1: implement detection and reaction for OS::Heat::InstanceGroup, AWS::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup, and OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup. Work item 2: enable clients to declare the health of a member of one of those scaling group types Work item 3: implement detection and reaction for OS::Heat::ResourceGroup. Work item 4: enable clients to declare the health of a member of OS::Heat::ResourceGroup Dependencies ============ No dependencies on other blueprints. Adds no dependencies on libraries or other external code.

added_lines: <title>Introduction</title> <para>Although most OpenStack architecture designs fall into one of the seven major scenarios outlined in other sections (compute focused, network focused, storage focused, general purpose, multi-site, hybrid cloud, and massively scalable), there are a few other use cases that are unique enough they can't be neatly categorized into one of the other major sections. This section discusses some of these unique use cases with some additional details and design considerations for each use case.</para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>Specialized Networking: This describes running networking-oriented software that may involve reading packets directly from the wire or participating in routing protocols.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Software-Defined Networking: This use case details both running an SDN controller from within OpenStack as well as participating in a software-defined network.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Desktop-as-a-Service: This is for organizations that want to run a virtualized desktop environment on a cloud. This can apply to private or public clouds.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>OpenStack on OpenStack: Some organizations are finding that it makes technical sense to build a multi-tiered cloud by running OpenStack on top of an OpenStack installation.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Specialized Hardware: Some highly specialized situations will require the use of specialized hardware devices from within the OpenStack environment.</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist>

This section discusses some of these unique use cases with some additional details and design considerations for each use case.</para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>Specialized Networking: This describes running networking-oriented software that may involve reading packets directly from the wire or participating in routing protocols.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Software-Defined Networking: This use case details both running an SDN controller from within OpenStack as well as participating in a software-defined network.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Desktop-as-a-Service: This is for organizations that want to run a virtualized desktop environment on a cloud. This can apply to private or public clouds.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>OpenStack on OpenStack: Some organizations are finding that it makes technical sense to build a multi-tiered cloud by running OpenStack on top of an OpenStack installation.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Specialized Hardware: Some highly specialized situations will require the use of specialized hardware devices from within the OpenStack environment.</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist>

subject: Bail out a little faster when object write affinity is off
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-05 05:48:56.000000000', 'files': ['swift/proxy/controllers/obj.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/0cefaaf8e0ce24f72fef80f8e48629ad13c68412', 'message': 'Bail out a little faster when object write affinity is off

This function was calling a couple functions prior to checking for
early bailout; if it did bail out, the results of those function calls

Change-Id: Ia023549a45355b44ebfb41212565c42f993415a9
'}]
commit_message:
Bail out a little faster when object write affinity is off

This function was calling a couple functions prior to checking for
early bailout; if it did bail out, the results of those function calls
were unused. Bail out earlier to avoid wasted work.

Change-Id: Ia023549a45355b44ebfb41212565c42f993415a9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/14/111914/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Don't fail tests if can't connect to NTP servers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-05 13:06:05.000000000', 'files': ['fuelweb_test/models/environment.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main/commit/7cd4cc1fb4dc7885163bde045682934f440a00a5', 'message': "Don't fail tests if can't connect to NTP servers

1) In case of temporary problems with internet connection on
host server ndpd/ntpdate on Fuel master can't synchronize
time with public NTP servers and system tests fail. Actually,
it isn't necessarily because slaves sync time from master
node and cluster time still will be identical, so we should
not interrupt system tests.
2) Tests should proceed with synchronizing time on slaves
only if ntpd on master node is ready for connections.
3) If ntpdate on slaves is unable to sync time with master
node, then raise exception and break test.

Change-Id: I81f19bbd2a542d540d53ea8bdb42537b83867ee9
Closes-bug: #1351279
"}]
commit_message:
Don't fail tests if can't connect to NTP servers

1) In case of temporary problems with internet connection on
host server ndpd/ntpdate on Fuel master can't synchronize
time with public NTP servers and system tests fail. Actually,
it isn't necessarily because slaves sync time from master
node and cluster time still will be identical, so we should
not interrupt system tests.
2) Tests should proceed with synchronizing time on slaves
only if ntpd on master node is ready for connections.
3) If ntpdate on slaves is unable to sync time with master
node, then raise exception and break test.

Change-Id: I81f19bbd2a542d540d53ea8bdb42537b83867ee9
Closes-bug: #1351279
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/08/112008/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: logger.error( ' trying to run ntpd: %s' % e) raise self.execute_remote_cmd(remote, 'hwclock -s') self.execute_remote_cmd(remote, 'service ntpd stop && ntpd -qg && ' 'service ntpd start') self.execute_remote_cmd(remote, 'hwclock -w') @logwrap remote = self.get_admin_remote() self.execute_remote_cmd(remote, 'hwclock -s') # Sync time using ntpd try: # If public NTP servers aren't accessible ntpdate will fail and # ntpd daemon shouldn't be restarted to avoid 'Server has gone # too long without sync' error while syncing time from slaves self.execute_remote_cmd(remote, "ntpdate -d $(awk '/^server/{print" " $2}' /etc/ntp.conf)") except AssertionError as e: logger.warning('Error occurred while synchronizing time on master' ': {0}'.format(e)) else: self.execute_remote_cmd(remote, 'service ntpd stop && ntpd -qg && ' 'service ntpd start') self.execute_remote_cmd(remote, 'hwclock -w') remote_date = remote.execute('date')['stdout'] logger.info("Master node time: {0}".format(remote_date)) @logwrap def execute_remote_cmd(self, remote, cmd, exit_code=0): result = remote.execute(cmd) assert_equal(result['exit_code'], exit_code, 'Failed to execute "{0}" on remote host: {1}'. format(cmd, result['stderr'])) return result['stdout']
deleted_lines: logger.warn( ' trying to run ntpdate: %s' % e) remote.execute('hwclock --hctosys') ntpd_exit = remote.execute("ntpdate -u $(awk '/^server/{print $2}'" " /etc/ntp.conf)")['exit_code'] assert_equal(0, ntpd_exit) remote.execute('hwclock -w') self.sync_node_time(self.get_admin_remote())

commit_message:
docs - Fix doc build errors with SQLAlchemy 0.9

The Nova docs failed to build when using SQLAlchemy 0.9. Among
the errors that are reported is this one:

nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py:docstring of nova.db.sqlalchemy.api.select:12:
WARNING: undefined label: coretutorial_selecting (if the link has no
caption the label must precede a section header)

nova/openstack/common/db/sqlalchemy/utils.py:docstring of
nova.openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy.utils.or_:26: WARNING: more than one target found for
cross-reference u'and_': nova.db.sqlalchemy.api.and_,
nova.virt.baremetal.db.sqlalchemy.migrate_repo.versions.006_move_prov_mac_address.and_

nova/virt/baremetal/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/006_move_prov_mac_address.py:
docstring of nova.virt.baremetal.db.sqlalchemy.migrate_repo.versions.
006_move_prov_mac_address.and_:35: WARNING: more than one target found for cross-reference
u'or_': nova.db.sqlalchemy.api.or_, nova.openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy.utils.or_

nova/virt/baremetal/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/006_move_prov_mac_address.py:
docstring of nova.virt.baremetal.db.sqlalchemy.migrate_repo.versions.
006_move_prov_mac_address.select:12: WARNING: undefined label: coretutorial_selecting
(if the link has no caption the label must precede a section header)

To fix this, the imports causing breaks were removed and changed to more specific/better
imports

Change-Id: I83cf38c03cef8bb3186160a660d30979cc303839

deleted_lines: from sqlalchemy.sql.expression import select compute_node_query = select(filter_columns(compute_node)).\ service_query = select(filter_columns(service)).\ query_insert = select([table], query_delete = select([column],

commit_message:
Adding utils, tests for them and fixing some pep8.

Change-Id: If0e9deafb8923d76beee8f2da07e913beeb4a962
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ec2-api refs/changes/07/111707/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Cloudscaling Group, Inc # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock import testtools from ec2api.api import ec2utils from ec2api import exception from ec2api.tests import matchers class EC2UtilsTestCase(testtools.TestCase): def test_get_ec2_id(self): self.assertEqual('vpc-000004d2', ec2utils.get_ec2_id(0x4d2, 'vpc')) self.assertEqual('vpc-000004d2', ec2utils.get_ec2_id(long(0x4d2), 'vpc')) self.assertRaises(OverflowError, ec2utils.get_ec2_id, -1, 'vpc') self.assertRaises(OverflowError, ec2utils.get_ec2_id, 0x123456789, 'vpc') self.assertRaises(TypeError, ec2utils.get_ec2_id, 'fake', 'vpc') self.assertRaises(TypeError, ec2utils.get_ec2_id, 1.1, 'vpc') @mock.patch('ec2api.db.api.IMPL') def test_get_db_item(self, db_api): item = {'fake_key': 'fake_value'} db_api.get_item_by_id.return_value = item def check_normal_flow(db_id, kind, ec2_id): item['id'] = db_id res = ec2utils.get_db_item('fake_context', kind, ec2_id) self.assertThat(res, matchers.DictMatches(item)) db_api.get_item_by_id.assert_called_once_with('fake_context', kind, db_id) db_api.reset_mock() check_normal_flow(0x001234af, 'vpc', 'vpc-001234af') check_normal_flow(0x22, 'igw', 'igw-22') def check_not_found(kind, ec2_id, item_id, ex_class): self.assertRaises(ex_class, ec2utils.get_db_item, 'fake_context', kind, ec2_id) db_api.get_item_by_id.assert_called_once_with('fake_context', kind, item_id) db_api.reset_mock() db_api.get_item_by_id.return_value = None check_not_found('vpc', 'vpc-22', 0x22, exception.InvalidVpcIDNotFound) check_not_found('igw', 'igw-22', 0x22, exception.InvalidInternetGatewayIDNotFound) check_not_found('subnet', 'subnet-22', 0x22, exception.InvalidSubnetIDNotFound) def test_validate_cidr(self): self.assertIsNone(ec2utils.validate_cidr('10.10.0.0/24', 'cidr')) def check_raise_invalid_parameter(cidr): self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidParameterValue, ec2utils.validate_cidr, cidr, 'cidr') check_raise_invalid_parameter('fake') check_raise_invalid_parameter('10.10/24') check_raise_invalid_parameter('10.10.0.0.0/24') check_raise_invalid_parameter('10.10.0.0') check_raise_invalid_parameter(' 10.10.0.0/24') check_raise_invalid_parameter('10.10.0.0/24 ') check_raise_invalid_parameter('.10.10.0.0/24 ') check_raise_invalid_parameter('-1.10.0.0/24') check_raise_invalid_parameter('10.256.0.0/24') check_raise_invalid_parameter('10.10.0.0/33') check_raise_invalid_parameter('10.10.0.0/-1') def check_raise_invalid_vpc_range(cidr, ex_class): self.assertRaises(ex_class, ec2utils.validate_vpc_cidr, cidr, ex_class) check_raise_invalid_vpc_range('10.10.0.0/15', exception.InvalidSubnetRange) check_raise_invalid_vpc_range('10.10.0.0/29', exception.InvalidVpcRange)

Author: OpenStack Proposal Bot <openstack-infra@lists.openstack.org>
Date:   Tue Jul 22 16:44:51 2014 +0000
Name:   Updated from global requirements

key changes:
- copied latest versions of existing modules
- added new module from common code - systemd
- updated openstack-common.conf to be consistent with really used modules
